overview: Philemon is Paul's personal appeal for a runaway slave named Onesimus, now a believer. Paul asks Philemon to receive him back as a brother, not property—a revolutionary application of the gospel.

verses.text: No longer as a bondservant but more than a bondservant, as a beloved brother—especially to me, but how much more to you, both in the flesh and in the Lord.
If he has wronged you at all, or owes you anything, charge that to my account.

passages.title: Paul's Appeal
passages.summary: Paul could command Philemon but instead appeals to love, offering to pay any debt owed, asking him to receive Onesimus as Paul himself.

facts.text: This is Paul's shortest letter—just 25 verses—and his most personal, addressing one individual about one situation.
Paul's offer to pay Onesimus's debt is a picture of what Christ does for us—charging our debt to His account.
Some scholars believe Onesimus later became the bishop of Ephesus mentioned by Ignatius.
The letter subtly undermines slavery by calling the slave a 'beloved brother'—equal in Christ.

figures.name: Paul
figures.description: The imprisoned apostle writing with grace and tact, modeling how the gospel transforms social relationships.

figures.name: Philemon
figures.description: A wealthy Colossian believer whose home hosted a church, now challenged to treat his slave as a brother.

figures.name: Onesimus
figures.description: A runaway slave who met Paul in prison, became a believer, and is now sent back with a transformed identity.

videos.title: Philemon Overview
videos.description: The Bible Project explores how the gospel transforms relationships.
